pages.text: Gobiconodon comes from the Early Cretaceous, with fossils being found in formations across Eurasia and Africa. It is a small gobiconodontid, growing up to 45 cm in diameter. Like most carnivorous predators, it possessed the usual sheering molariform teeth, canine-like incisors and powerful jaw and forelimb muscles. But unlike most carnivorous predators, and even other eutriconodonts,

its lower canines had become vestigial, with only the first lower incisor pair becoming large and canine-like. The generic name derives from the place name 'Gobi', where the first fossils were found; and the English word 'conodont', to mean 'cone-tooth', from the Greek words 'kônos' and 'odoús'.
